Description: The student's capacity to direct and sustain attention on tasks, activities, and instructions appropriate for their age and setting.
The degree to which the student is drawn away from tasks by unrelated stimuli, thoughts, or events in the environment.
The student's ability to complete assignments, activities, and multi-step instructions from start to finish.
The student's ability to keep track of belongings, organize work, and manage time and responsibilities.
The student's typical level of physical movement, restlessness, and need for motion during activities that require sitting or stillness.
The student's ability to pause, consider consequences, and regulate impulsive responses before acting or speaking.
The student's capacity to wait their turn, delay gratification, and tolerate situations that require waiting.
The student's general emotional tone and typical mood patterns throughout the school day and over time.
Observable signs that the student experiences persistent sadness, hopelessness, or diminished enjoyment in activities.
The student's expressed or apparent sense of personal value, confidence in abilities, and overall self-regard.
The student's capacity to experience enjoyment, show enthusiasm, and engage with activities that are typically pleasurable.
The extent to which the student shows excessive or persistent worry about various aspects of life, school, or the future.
The student's concerns about peer acceptance, social performance, or being judged or embarrassed by others.
The student's level of distress or worry when separated from parents, caregivers, or familiar settings.
Observable physical symptoms that accompany worry or fear, such as stomachaches, headaches, or complaints without medical cause.
The student's ability to cope with challenges, mistakes, setbacks, or situations that don't go as expected without becoming overwhelmed.
The student's capacity to manage feelings of anger, irritability, or annoyance without losing control or behaving aggressively.
How quickly and effectively the student returns to a calm, regulated state after experiencing strong emotions.
The degree to which the student's emotional expressions match the situation and are communicated in socially appropriate ways.
The student's ability to form, develop, and maintain positive friendships and relationships with same-age peers.
The student's interest in and initiation of social interactions, group activities, and cooperative play or work.
The student's use of appropriate social behaviors such as sharing, taking turns, conversation skills, and reading social cues.
The student's ability to recognize others' feelings, show compassion, and act with consideration toward peers and adults.
The student's willingness and ability to follow classroom rules, school expectations, and adult directions.
The student's tendency toward truthful communication and taking responsibility for their own actions.
The student's treatment of their own belongings and those of others, including shared classroom and school materials.
The frequency and intensity of verbal or physical conflicts, arguments, or hostile interactions with peers or adults.
The occurrence of behaviors intended to hurt, intimidate, or harm others physically, verbally, or relationally.
The student's internal motivation, effort, and persistence when engaging with academic material and learning challenges.
The student's active involvement in classroom discussions, activities, and learning opportunities.
The student's consistency, care, and thoroughness when completing assignments and managing academic responsibilities.
The student's ability to express thoughts, needs, and ideas clearly through verbal or written communication.
The student's ability to pay attention when others speak, follow verbal instructions, and demonstrate understanding.
The student's ability to engage in reciprocal conversation, including taking turns, staying on topic, and responding appropriately.
The student's ability to adapt when plans, routines, or expectations change unexpectedly.
The student's comfort level and ability to cope when facing new people, places, activities, or challenges.
The student's ability to smoothly shift from one activity, setting, or task to another throughout the school day.
The student's ability to initiate and sustain work or activities without constant adult direction or supervision.
The student's ability to identify problems, generate solutions, and work through challenges with increasing autonomy.
The student's ability to recognize when help is needed and to seek assistance from appropriate sources in constructive ways.
The student's apparent energy, alertness, and physical vitality throughout the school day.
Observable signs that the student may be experiencing inadequate sleep, fatigue, or sleep-related difficulties.
The frequency of the student's reports of physical symptoms such as headaches, stomachaches, or general discomfort without apparent medical cause.

Brief Description: Ability to maintain focus on tasks
Description: The degree to which a student can sustain mental effort and attention on academic tasks, conversations, and activities without losing track of what they are doing
How easily a student is pulled away from tasks by noises, movements, or other environmental stimuli, and how well they can filter out irrelevant information
The extent to which a student has trouble remaining seated, staying calm, or controlling physical movement when expected to be still
A student's ability to modulate their energy level appropriately for different settings—settling down when needed and maintaining sufficient energy for tasks
The tendency to stop and think before speaking or acting, rather than immediately responding to urges or reacting without reflection
A student's ability to wait their turn, stand in line, delay gratification, and refrain from interrupting others during conversations or activities
How well a student copes with powerful emotions like anger, frustration, excitement, or disappointment without becoming overwhelmed or acting out
The degree to which a student maintains a relatively stable emotional baseline versus experiencing frequent or rapid shifts between different mood states
How quickly and effectively a student can calm down and return to normal functioning after experiencing a setback, disappointment, or emotional upset
The extent to which a student worries about things—including future events, past mistakes, performance, or potential problems—beyond what situations warrant
A student's level of anxiety or self-consciousness when interacting with others, being observed, performing in front of people, or meeting new peers
Concerns or fears specifically related to school—including worry about tests, being called on, going to school, or academic performance
The frequency and depth of a student's feelings of sadness, unhappiness, or emotional pain that persist beyond typical responses to disappointing events
A student's capacity to feel interested in activities, experience pleasure and enjoyment, and approach life with curiosity rather than apathy
How a student feels about themselves—including their confidence in their abilities, sense of being liked and valued, and overall self-regard
A student's ability to make friends, maintain friendships over time, and experience the reciprocal give-and-take that characterizes healthy peer relationships
How comfortable and at ease a student feels when interacting with peers, adults, and people they don't know well
A student's general ability to interact positively with other students—sharing, taking turns, resolving conflicts, and being accepted by the peer group
The degree to which a student follows classroom rules, adult instructions, and behavioral expectations at school without frequent reminders or resistance
The frequency and intensity of a student's aggressive behaviors—including fighting, threatening, bullying, or being cruel to others
A student's tendency to be truthful, avoid cheating, respect others' property, and behave in ways that are honest and trustworthy

Brief Description: Drive to do well in school
Description: A student's willingness to try their best, persist with challenging work, and put forth genuine effort on academic tasks
The extent to which a student finishes what they start, completes homework and classwork, and follows through on academic responsibilities
A student's sense of feeling safe, welcome, and engaged at school—including enjoyment of being there and feeling like they matter to the school community
A student's ability to keep track of necessary items like assignments, books, supplies, and personal belongings without frequently losing them
How well a student can organize tasks and activities—including breaking work into steps, planning ahead, and approaching assignments systematically
A student's tendency to be kind, considerate, helpful, and caring toward peers—including offering help, sharing, and showing concern for others' feelings
A student's inclination to treat others fairly, take turns, share resources equitably, and recognize when something is unfair

Brief Description: Ability to concentrate and maintain focus on tasks
Description: The student's capacity to direct and sustain mental effort on activities, including listening, following instructions, and staying on task despite distractions

Brief Description: Ability to plan and manage tasks and materials
Description: The student's capacity to keep track of belongings, manage time, prioritize tasks, and maintain orderly approaches to schoolwork and daily activities

Brief Description: Following through on assignments and activities
Description: The student's tendency to finish what they start, persist through challenges, and complete work without excessive prompting
Observable patterns of fidgeting, squirming, leaving seat, or excessive movement in situations requiring calm and stillness
The student's ability to pause, consider consequences, wait their turn, and regulate urges to act or speak without thinking
The student's capacity to monitor and adjust their own behavior to meet situational demands without constant external prompting
The student's typical emotional tone, including general cheerfulness, contentment, and capacity for enjoyment in daily activities
Observable indicators that the student may be experiencing persistent sadness, loss of interest, hopelessness, or emotional withdrawal
The student's sense of personal value, competence, and confidence in their own abilities and worthiness

Brief Description: Tendency to be anxious or concerned
Description: The frequency and intensity of the student's worry, nervousness, or apprehension about various aspects of life

Brief Description: Strong negative reactions to specific situations
Description: The student's experience of intense fear or avoidance related to particular objects, situations, or circumstances

Brief Description: Physical and emotional reactions to pressure
Description: How the student's body and mind respond to stressful situations, including physical tension, nervousness, and difficulty relaxing
The student's ability to form and maintain friendships, be accepted by peers, and navigate the social world of same-age children
The student's competence in reading social cues, taking turns in conversation, showing empathy, and behaving appropriately in social situations
How comfortable and confident the student feels when interacting with others, including shyness, social hesitation, or fear of negative evaluation
The student's tendency to follow rules, respect authority, and comply with reasonable expectations from adults

Brief Description: Hostile or hurtful behavior toward others
Description: The frequency and intensity of behaviors intended to harm, intimidate, threaten, or bully others, whether physical or verbal
The student's tendency to be honest, avoid deception, and respect the belongings and rights of others
How well the student manages frustration, disappointment, and situations that don't go their way without excessive upset
The student's ability to experience anger without losing control, and to express upset in ways that don't harm self or others
The steadiness of the student's emotional state, including predictability of responses and recovery from emotional upset
The student's drive to learn, willingness to put forth effort, and intrinsic interest in academic activities
The student's overall orientation toward school, including enjoyment, perceived relevance, and sense of belonging
Observable patterns in the student's work quality, including effort, accuracy, and meeting academic expectations
The student's ability to function autonomously, solve problems independently, and take initiative without excessive adult support

Brief Description: Adjusting to changes and new situations
Description: How well the student handles transitions, changes in routine, new environments, and unexpected circumstances
The student's inclination to offer help, support, and assistance to peers and adults without being asked
The student's ability to collaborate, share, take turns, and work productively as part of a group
The student's capacity to recognize and respond sensitively to others' emotional states and to show genuine care and compassion
The student's ability to express ideas, needs, and emotions in ways that others can understand
The student's ability to comprehend verbal and nonverbal communication from teachers and peers
The student's general energy, alertness, and physical vigor during the school day
The frequency of the student's complaints about headaches, stomachaches, or other physical symptoms without clear medical cause

Brief Description: Signs of inadequate or poor sleep
Description: Observable indicators that the student may not be getting adequate rest, including fatigue, difficulty waking, or mentions of sleep problems
